I had what you might call a slight NDE when I was 8 years old. I drowned in a lake, then at some point someone saw me and swam out and saved me. At first it was very scary when I knew that there was no one around close enough to hear my screams. I couldn't swim, so I dog-paddled as long as I could. Then, when I couldn't stay afloat any longer, I remember thinking, "this is it". I just relaxed and floated down, down, down. I remember in that moment, not sure how long it was, I felt this amazing peace fall over me. It was so nice I didn't want it to end. Didn't see any light, a tunnel, or anything like that. Maybe because my heart didn't stop beating, don't know . Then, someone came from out of the woods, swam out to the middle of the lake and down very deep and pulled me up by my pony tail. I coughed and sputtered when he set me on the beach, asked if I was ok, then he was gone. I didn't ever tell anyone about it until I was an adult. Not sure why, it was just very traumatic as a child and very personal. Later in life, I was at a Bible study and the subject came up about angels being around us when we don't even know it because they can materialize to look like humans. "Oh my God!" I thought back on that day. Could it have been an angel that saved me? Don't know. But, I was never afraid of death after that. Guess that's why I was a daredevil. I surfed 15-foot waves in my youth, climb tall towers in the river and dove off, climbed way too high in trees, etc. Now I'm 70 and so glad to have those memories. I wrote a book about where I believe we go when we die. It's on Amazon, but I also made a short video on it. Check it out and let me know what you think. Blessings everyone. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uOiX-_PWDs4&t=1s

We do have life after death! First, for the believer in Jesus Christ, the Bible tells us that after death believers’ souls/spirits are taken to heaven, because their sins are forgiven by having received Christ as Savior (John 3:16, 18, 36). For believers, death is to be “away from the body and at home with the Lord” (2 Corinthians 5:6-8; Philippians 1:23). However, passages such as 1 Corinthians 15:50-54 and 1 Thessalonians 4:13-17 describe believers being resurrected and given glorified bodies. If believers go to be with Christ immediately after death, what is the purpose of this resurrection? It seems that while the souls/spirits of believers go to be with Christ immediately after death, the physical body remains in the grave “sleeping.” At the resurrection of believers, the physical body is resurrected, glorified, and then reunited with the soul/spirit. This reunited and glorified body-soul-spirit will be the possession of believers for eternity in the new heavens and new earth (Revelation 21-22).

Second, for those who do not receive Jesus Christ as Savior, death means everlasting punishment. However, similar to the destiny of believers, unbelievers also seem to be sent immediately to a temporary holding place, to await their final resurrection, judgment, and eternal destiny. Luke 16:22-23 describes a rich man being tormented immediately after death. Revelation 20:11-15 describes all the unbelieving dead being resurrected, judged at the great white throne, and then being cast into the lake of fire. Unbelievers, then, are not sent to hell (the lake of fire) immediately after death, but rather are in a temporary realm of judgment and condemnation. However, even though unbelievers are not instantly sent to the lake of fire, their immediate fate after death is not a pleasant one. The rich man cried out, “I am in agony in this fire” (Luke 16:24).

Therefore, after death, a person resides in a “temporary” heaven or hell. After this temporary realm, at the final resurrection, a person’s eternal destiny will not change. The precise “location” of that eternal destiny is what changes. Believers will ultimately be granted entrance into the new heavens and new earth (Revelation 21:1). Unbelievers will ultimately be sent to the lake of fire (Revelation 20:11-15). These are the final, eternal destinations of all people—based entirely on whether or not they had trusted Jesus Christ alone for salvation (Matthew 25:46; John 3:36).

This is what really happens when you die. But first, ask yourself what the authority is for what you believe. It is basically just your own opinion, and so it is worthless, and certainly not worth taking a gamble on.

My authority is NOT my own opinion. My authority is the English King James Bible, which is the inspired and preserved Word of God. Don't make the mistake of dismissing it (which you have probably been trained to do) without first checking it out.

The Bible says that you do not just stop when you die. Your soul goes either to heaven with the Lord, or into hell, which is a place of torment in flames. (See Luke 16:19-31.) John 3:36 says "He that believeth on the Son [Jesus] hath everlasting life: and he that believeth not the Son shall not see life; but the wrath of God abideth on him.". Hebrews 9:27 says "It is appointed unto men once to die, but after this the judgment."

ARE THE DEAD REALLY DEAD?

Death just might be one of the most misunderstood subjects today. For many, death is shrouded in mystery and evokes dread, uncertainty, and hopelessness. Others believe that their deceased loved ones are not dead at all, but instead live with them or in other realms. Millions are confused about the relationship between the body, spirit, and soul. But does it really matter what you believe? Yes—absolutely! What you believe about the dead will have a profound impact on what happens to you in the near future.

1. How did humans get here in the first place?
“The Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living being” (Genesis 2:7).

Answer: God made us from dust in the beginning.

2. What happens when a person dies?
“Then the dust will return to the earth as it was, and the spirit will return to God who gave it” (Ecclesiastes 12:7).

Answer: The body turns to dust again, and the spirit goes back to God, who gave it. The spirit of every person who dies—whether saved or unsaved—returns to God at death.
3. What is the “spirit” that returns to God at death?
“The body without the spirit is dead” (James 2:26).
“The spirit of God is in my nostrils” (Job 27:3 KJV).

Answer: The spirit that returns to God at death is the breath of life. Nowhere in all of God’s book does the “spirit” have any life, wisdom, or feeling after a person dies. It is the “breath of life” and nothing more.

4. What is a "soul"?
“The Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul” (Genesis 2:7 KJV).

Answer: A soul is a living being. A soul is always a combination of two things: body plus breath. A soul cannot exist unless body and breath are combined. God’s Word teaches that we are souls—not that we have souls.

5. Do souls die?
“The soul that sinneth, it shall die” (Ezekiel 18:20 KJV).
“Every living soul died in the sea” (Revelation 16:3 KJV).

Answer: According to God’s Word, souls do die! We are souls, and souls die. Man is mortal (Job 4:17).
Only God is immortal (1 Timothy 6:15, 16). The concept of an undying, immortal soul is not found in the Bible, which teaches that souls are subject to death.

Do good people go to heaven when they die?
“All who are in the graves will hear His voice and come forth” (John 5:28, 29).
“David … is both dead and buried, and his tomb is with us to this day. … For David did not ascend into the heavens” (Acts 2:29, 34).
“If I wait, the grave is mine house” (Job 17:13 KJV).

Answer: No. People do not go to heaven or to hell at death. They don’t go anywhere—but they wait in their graves for the resurrection.

7. How much does one know or comprehend after death?
“The living know that they will die; but the dead know nothing, and they have no more reward, for the memory of them is forgotten. Also their love, their hatred, and their envy have now perished; nevermore will they have a share in anything done under the sun. … There is no work or device or knowledge or wisdom in the grave where you are going” (Ecclesiastes 9:5, 6, 10).
“The dead do not praise the Lord” (Psalm 115:17).

Answer: God says that the dead know absolutely nothing!

8. But can’t the dead communicate with the living, and aren’t they aware of what the living are doing?
“Man lies down and does not rise. Till the heavens are no more, they will not awake nor be roused from their sleep. … His sons come to honor, and he does not know it; they are brought low, and he does not perceive it” (Job 14:12, 21).
“Nevermore will they have a share in anything done under the sun” (Ecclesiastes 9:6).

Answer: No. The dead cannot contact the living, nor do they know what the living are doing. They are dead. Their thoughts have perished (Psalm 146:4 KJV).

9. Jesus called the unconscious state of the dead “sleep” in John 11:11–14. How long will they sleep?
“Man lies down and does not rise. Till the heavens are no more” (Job 14:12).
“The day of the Lord will come … in which the heavens will pass away” (2 Peter 3:10).

Answer: The dead will sleep until the great day of the Lord at the end of the world. In death humans are totally unconscious with no activity or knowledge of any kind.

10. What happens to the righteous dead at the second coming of Christ?
“Behold, I am coming quickly, and My reward is with Me, to give to every one according to his work” (Revelation 22:12).
“The Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout. … And the dead in Christ will rise. … And thus we shall always be with the Lord” (1 Thessalonians 4:16, 17).
“We shall all be changed—in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye … and the dead will be raised incorruptible. … For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality” (1 Corinthians 15:51–53).

Answer: They will be rewarded. They will be raised, given immortal bodies, and caught up to meet the Lord in the air. There would be no purpose in a resurrection if people were taken to heaven at death.

11. What was the devil’s first lie on Earth?
“The serpent said to the woman, ‘You will not surely die’ ” (Genesis 3:4).
“That serpent of old, called the Devil and Satan” (Revelation 12:9).

Answer: You will not die.

12. Why did the devil lie to Eve about death? Could this subject be more important than we think?
Answer: The devil’s lie that we will not die is one of the pillars of his teachings. For thousands of years, he has worked powerful, deceptive miracles to trick people into thinking they are receiving messages from the spirits of the dead. (Examples: Magicians of Egypt—Exodus 7:11; Woman of Endor—1 Samuel 28:3–25; Sorcerers—Daniel 2:2; A slave girl—Acts 16:16–18.)

A Solemn Warning
In the near future, Satan will again use sorcery—as he did in the prophet Daniel’s day—to deceive the world (Revelation 18:23). Sorcery is a supernatural agency that claims to receive its power and wisdom from the spirits of the dead.

Posing as Jesus' Disciples
Posing as godly loved ones who have died, saintly clergymen who are now dead, Bible prophets, or even the apostles of Christ (2 Corinthians 11:13), Satan and his angels will deceive billions. Those who believe the dead are alive, in any form, will likely be deceived.

14. Why will God's people not be deceived?
“They received the word with all readiness, and searched the Scriptures daily to find out whether these things were so” (Acts 17:11).
“If they do not speak according to this word, it is because there is no light in them” (Isaiah 8:20).

Answer: God’s people will know from their study of His book that the dead are dead, not alive. They will know that a “spirit” claiming to be a deceased loved one is really a devil! God’s people will reject all teachers and miracle workers who claim to receive special “light” or work miracles by contacting the spirits of the dead. And God’s people will likewise reject as dangerous and false all teachings that claim the dead are alive in any form, anywhere.

15. Back in Moses’ day, what did God command should be done to people who taught that the dead were alive?
“A man or a woman who is a medium, or who has familiar spirits, shall surely be put to death; they shall stone them with stones” (Leviticus 20:27).

Answer: God insisted that mediums and others with “familiar spirits” (who claimed to be able to contact the dead) should be stoned to death. This shows how God regards the false teaching that the dead are alive.

16. Will the righteous people who are raised in the resurrection ever die again?
“Those who are counted worthy to attain that age, and the resurrection from the dead … nor can they die anymore” (Luke 20:35, 36).

“God will wipe away every tear from their eyes; there shall be no more death, nor sorrow, nor crying. There shall be no more pain, for the former things have passed away” (Revelation 21:4).

Answer: No! Death, sorrow, crying, and tragedy will never enter into God’s new kingdom. “When this corruptible has put on incorruption, and this mortal has put on immortality, then shall be brought to pass the saying that is written: ‘Death is swallowed up in victory’ ” (1 Corinthians 15:54).

17. Belief in reincarnation is expanding rapidly today. Is this teaching biblical?
“The living know that they will die; but the dead know nothing. … Nevermore will they have a share in anything done under the sun” (Ecclesiastes 9:5, 6).

Answer: Almost half the people on earth believe in reincarnation, a teaching that the soul never dies but is instead continually reborn in a different kind of body with each succeeding generation. This teaching, however, is contrary to Scripture.

The Bible Says
After death a person: returns to dust (Psalms 104:29), knows nothing (Ecclesiastes 9:5), possesses no mental powers (Psalms 146:4), has nothing to do with anything on earth (Ecclesiastes 9:6), does not live (2 Kings 20:1), waits in the grave (Job 17:13), and continues not (Job 14:1, 2).

Satan's Invention
We learned in questions 11 and 12 that Satan invented the teaching that the dead are alive. Reincarnation, channeling, communication with spirits, spirit worship, and the "undying soul" are all inventions of Satan, with one aim to convince people that when you die you are not really dead. When people believe that the dead are alive, "spirits of devils, working miracles" (Revelation 16:14) and posing as spirits of the dead will be able to deceive and lead them astray virtually 100 percent of the time (Matthew 24:24).

The thing about the "bathroom" is not factual. Speaking from actual experience of being in immediate area of persons who have passed away: One male, 68 yrs old, cancer- no soiling. Two young males (teens?) gunshot- no toilet "accidents". One 50s white male- diabetes, unk cause (probably complications of diabetes, died in sleep) no accidents (I include both urination and defecation) one very unhealthy, 70s-age male cirrhosis of the liver, dehydration and malnutrition- no soiling. One male, age 46- ateriosclerosis, heart failure- no soiling. I suspect, the self soiling rumor may have come from persons who have were very frightened when they passed on, perhaps loosening of the bowels pre-death. Other than that, the fixation some people have on this is pretty disrespectful and downright foul.

I would like to share an important message of hope with you. In fact, this is the most important message of all time. This message of hope is the message that “...Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners...” - (1 Timothy 1:15) But what does that even mean?

The Bible says that “all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God” – (Romans 3:23). That means me, you, and everyone else; we’re all broken people who have fallen short of the righteousness of God. The Bible tells us that “the wages of sin is death” – (Romans 6:23a). This death is a spiritual death called the second death that comes after the physical death of the body. When a sinner dies, they must pay a debt that they owe because of their sin. The only way to personally pay that debt is for us to spend eternity in a place called Hell. Hell is not a good place and the Bible describes it as a “lake which burneth with fire and brimstone” – (Revelation 21:8b)


But wait! There is good news! God loves us and does not want anyone to go to Hell. “But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.” – (Romans 5:8) That’s right, God loves you even though you are a sinner, so much so that He offered His Son as a sacrifice/ransom for your sins so that you can spend eternity in Heaven. The Bible says Heaven is a place where “God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes; and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying, neither shall there be any more pain: for the former things are passed away.” – (Revelation 21:4)


On that day when Jesus willingly offered Himself as a sacrifice by dying on the cross, He was receiving the punishment we deserve for our sin. It’s as if He wrote a check that is paid-in-full for the sin debt that you owe. But how do you cash that check? How can you be saved from having to spend eternity in Hell? A man in the Bible asked that very question when he said “Sirs, what must I do to be saved? And they said, Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house.” – (Acts 16:30-31) According to the Bible, all you must do to be saved is believe that Jesus died on the cross paying the price for all the sins that you have ever done or will ever do. Jesus said “Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth on me hath everlasting life.” – (John 6:47) Simply trust Jesus as your only hope to spend eternity in Heaven. “Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me.” – (John 14:6)


Being saved has nothing to do with how good you are; but how good God is. “For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.” – (Eph. 2:8-9) Salvation is just that, a free gift from God received purely by faith.


“For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.” – (John 3:16) That is what it means when the Bible says that Christ Jesus came to save sinners. By ourselves, we are on a path that leads only to destruction. But through the blood Jesus shed for you can you find hope and forgiveness.


I invite you right now to make the most important decision you can ever make. Would you like to be forgiven of your sins and have assurance that you are going to go to Heaven? All you must do is make the genuine decision in your heart to trust in the Lord Jesus Christ and His finished work on the cross as your only way to live for eternity in Heaven. Trust Him. That’s all. Stop believing in yourself and believe in Jesus. Place your faith in the Son of God. If you want to make this decision, simply call out to the Lord. “whoever calls on the name of the Lord shall be saved.” – (Romans 10:13)

There's overwhelming accounts of people going through literal journeys while they were clinically dead. This means cognitive function is non-existent, no perception, no reactions, thought as we know it ceases. Yet somehow, people can recount grandiose adventures, accurately describe the environment around them via out of body experiences,  and describe dead relatives they've yet to even meet, just to list a few examples. I truly believe we just don't know enough about the quantum aspects of consciousness to truly decipher what happens when one dies. I'm a hardcore advocate for logic and science, but something like this... it's pretty divine. Personally, I believe religion and science converge in a matter like this. I find it interesting that the bible states that thoughts cease until judgement day, resembling the scientific notion that death is like the total deprivation of sensation and perception. I don't know honestly, the concept of heaven is sounding a lot less like wishful thinking and a lot more like science we can't even begin to understand.

We were nothingness/ no consciousness before we were born, and we will go back to being nothingness/ no consciousness after we die. Anything else is wishful thinking, or not wanting to face what we all deep down know what is coming for us. It can come at any moment, and we are gone forever. All we are, all our memories, all gone. All we have known our whole existence is consciousness. Even when we are unconscious, we still have an awareness of consciousness. But, death is no consciousness, no thought, for eternity. It's easy to let the fear of that dominate one's life. The fear of it coming at any time. The regret over the waste of our life. But, I've always seen this as a positive. It's a different way of living life, than the 90% of the population of the world that believes in life after death. If you live on after death, being in perfect paradise for all of eternity, what does these few decade you're alive really matter in the face of that? Yet, if one truly lets in that they can die at any moment and be nothing, be completely gone, then every single moment is truly precious. You are grateful with every ounce of your being for this gift of existence. Living fully every moment, not letting fear stop you from living full out. Because it can all end the very next moment or the next moment, and 'someday' will never come.

There is no Life After Death, and here's why:
Energy is neither created nor destroyed. When we die, metabolic energy tied up in our cells will be used in the decomposition process, but what about the electrical energy in our brains/bodies? This is a measurable amount of energy that at the moment of death is no longer required by the body/brain and has to go somewhere. So is there a measurable radiation of heat at the moment of death?
First, electrical energy is nothing special. Just like the chemical energy in our bodies, it breaks down into heat. For example, the heat given off by light bulbs is a result of electrical energy. When electricity is flowing to a light bulb, that’s where the electrical energy is going; it’s turning into light. When you pull the plug (so to speak) what tiny, tiny amount of electrical energy there is in the wires runs out almost immediately.
The term “electrical energy” is actually a little vague. So, to be specific, in our nervous system there are tiny ion pumps that maintain an imbalance of charges between the inside and outside of the nerve cells. When a nerve cell fires, charges are allowed to suddenly flow through the cell membrane in a process called an “action potential“. There are mechanisms that maintain an imbalance of charge, and that imbalance is drained a little bit every time the nerve fires.
Death (excluding spectacular deaths) isn’t instantaneous. In fact, what with medical science, it’s become more and more difficult to even define when people are dead. Time was you could define death as being a lack of heartbeat, but people have come back from worse. Death is more of a breakdown of the whole system, as opposed to a sudden event. The heart stops pumping, oxygen and nutrients stop going where they’re needed, and in short order the nerve cells in the body lose the wherewithal to pump ions. Like batteries that are no longer being recharged, they run down. Nothing special. Like every kind of energy, whether electrical, kinetic, the electrical potential in the body eventually becomes heat energy (it’s an entropy thing).
The energy we “carry around” takes the form of chemical energy like fats and sugars. When our nervous system creates electrical energy we lose an equal amount of chemical energy. So, rather than being energy itself, life is all about moving energy around from one form to another.
There are a few kinds of energy, but spiritual energy doesn’t seem to be one of them. In terms of physical energy, the difference between a living body and a very recently dead body is just a question of how that energy is being organized. Living creatures in general are very good at using chemical energy for things like moving, growing, etc. Newly dead creatures have about the same amount of chemical energy, it’s just that they don’t use it. Instead, whatever comes along to consume the body uses it (whether that’s fire or decomposition or whatever).
To date, there are no confirmable experiments that show that anything special happens during death, other than a general “shutting down”. In particular, nothing that’s both “inspiring” and verifiable seems to suddenly leave the body when we die, materially or energetically.'

My family has an 11 month old puppy (shes gonna be 1 year old in october) and the thing that made me the saddest was when I found out from the vet, I was a distraught mess for a whole month and the saddest part of it was when my mum told me that she would have to call one of my grandparents closest friends who is also a vet to come and put the dog down a week later (it was suppost to happen on Friday 30th October). I almost started crying at my weekly girl guides meeting (none of them have ever seen me cry and when my dog came down to say goodbye to everyone, I almost cried. All my leaders tried to make me feel better and it worked until I went to bed that night. On the thursday, some close family friends came over and took the rest of the food that he hadnt eaten to give to their dogs. That same day while we were having dinner, my mum noticed that he was starting to pass and he died surrounded by the whole family. My mum had to call my grandparents and uncle around to my house. My grandmother spent the whole time trying to calm me down and to say her final goodbye to him whereas my mum, dad, grandfather and uncle dug a hole in the flower garden in the back of our backyard and when it came to the time where we had to bury the dog, I wouldnt let anyone do it as it would make me cry even more. They eventually asked if I wanted to help carry him outside to his resting place and I was ok with doing that. After I went outside with the dead dog in my arms, I put him in the hole and ran over to find his favourite toy and I picked some lavender for the family that wasnt there and placed them in the hole with the dog. I went to bed crying that night and when I woke up in the morning, my eyes were wet which ment I cried while I was asleep cause I missed him so much. At school the next day, I asked my friends to send an email to all the teachers I had that day saying that I was going through a hard time and that I may not be completely on focus My teachers were all very supportive. I originally wasnt going to go trick or treating that year but when my friends invited me to go with them, I couldnt say no and I thought that it would take my mind of that. It worked but when I got home, I remembered that he wasnt there to greet me so I went to the kitchen and placed the triple butter popcorn I got in the microwave and went to my room to eat what I had. Only problem was that I was so far into the grieving process, I didnt let anyone come in my room and ate all the things I got that year. For the next few weeks, I went outside to his burial site (which now has a new lavendar bush growing on top as a memory of the dog) and always went through my day at school and what I did. I ended up taking half an hour to say goodnight to my parents (as im the oldest child in my family, I get to stay up later) and they tucked me into bed, which they haven't done since I was 8 or 9 years old. My friends and everyone who knew me were really supportive. I still find telling this story of his death hard but I know that its a fact of life and he nearly survived past the average age of the breed.
R.I.P my dog Winston (Age 12)

It's really not that complicated. When you die, your brain shuts down. When your brain shuts down, you can't think. That's what's gonna happen when you die. The only thing you leave behind is a rotting bag of flesh and bones. A body with no consciousness is the same thing as any inanimate matter (car, building, wood, glass, etc) with no consciousness.

AsapSCIENCE , I want to know something. My dad died about 6-7 weeks ago (April 1st, 2017). I wasn't there, he was is Orlando, FL and we live in Indiana. My dad was a big dude, weighing in around 400-450 lbs. He had been having kidney trouble for about 2 years. When they did the autopsy, they notice he had an enlarged heart, about three times the normal size. Could you please make a video to show me how his body was shutting down?
By the way, the day he died he woke up and had trouble breathing. He thought i was a fluid build-up because the same thing happened 3 months prior. Then it got worse. My cousin called an ambulance and they rushed him to the local hospital. When they got into the emergency room, his heart stopped. Luckily, they had some defibrillators there and began the procedure. However, this wasn't enough and they were unable to revive him.
My dad was born March 30th, 1984 and died April 1st, 2017, two days after his 33rd birthday.
Thanks for taking your time to read this comment.

Farewell,
-An 11-year-old from Indiana

The video starts out by saying that WE have to deal with OUR OWN death, but who is the consciousness that has to deal with it? Who is the proprieter?This clip only describes the degradation of the physical form, but doesn't refer to the experiencer. Consciousness has never  (and will never) be explained in terms of brain chemistry or synaptic processes, because these things are symptoms of consciousness (not causative principles ). To believe so is to subscribe to Dr Frankenstein's theory. True human life is to inquire about these differences through the many paths of yogic and meditative practice - where one can directly experience the nature of consciousness through a prescribed process. That is the greatest gift. Science is important for material analysis, but it can only take us to the barest perimeter of true knowledge, which is ultimately obtained via internal realization. I believe that consciousness is irreducable to matter - but material activity is evidence of the consciousness behind it. Others contend the opposite. Both are beliefs. The challenge is to decide which contention is the more intelligent - and where will that decision take us? Judging by the state of our modern 'advanced' materialistic society, the fruits are not so great.

As a rational person, I spent most of my life using science as a way to justify everything but recently I lost someone very important in my life and for the first time I realized that science wasn't appropriate. I was so intrigued when I watched this video a while back and now it's so painful to think about. The factual nature of science can sometimes be so dark and calloused. If you are here because you lost someone DONT watch this video. Go and read beautiful quotes about life and death and try to see our existence as being more than physical. If we see ourselves as just bone skin and tissue we will live in constant fear of death. I like to think of the physical component of life as a gift from God to help us with our mission here on earth and it should never be about the gifts we receive but the ones we give, so while you're here in life, share the gift of love and joy with your family and friends so that when you die, they won't be here watching this video cause they'll be so grateful for the gifts you left for them, they won't notice the ones you took to the afterlife with you :)

A strange coping mechanism for me when my grandma passed away was to accept this process happened to her remains and imagine it, albeit in a not so grotesque way. She, along with my parents, came to the US from Turkey so it was her wish to be buried as a Muslim. We made sure she had all the proper prayer and rituals, and part of it is no embalming and no enclosed casket. Because of laws, however, she had to be put in a casket but we were told the bottom had many holes drilled into it so the "elements" could get inside. While it sounds morbid or dark to think of a loved one having this done to them, for me it allowed me to accept that she was gone. Her body was no more. It also helped a little to imagine that she returned to the Earth and joined the cycle of life.

Could you expand on the brain activity surging due to oxygen depletion? I take it that the brain realizes it needs oxygen and so it sends out a S.O.S. for their body to breathe? Does the persons brain becomes acutely aware of their struggle? Or does the brain surge offer heightened hearing?  And what about a person who is beheaded? I am almost positive that this type of injury (abruptly severed head) is *NO* guarantee of an instantaneous death either! And nor would I be a bit surprised to learn that the auditory and visual reflexes remain directly after their execution? Maybe a Guillotined execution is similar to the sensation drowning? Weee, nuff said bout macabre aspects...eh? (Hah)  Hmmm, this topic also reminds me of a favorite 'Woody Allen' quote as well: "Death?! I'm not afraid of death, I just don't want to be there when it happens!" (Grin) I also wanted to mention that Hospice offers the best solution for end stage comfort. Anyone with a life threatening illness of approximately 8 months or less is able to hook up with Hospice. And should the person decides to go into the hospital at the end, that too is okay. They will send in a hospice nurse for 1:1 care when their health starts to deteriorate.  Yup, hook me up with a Foley cath and heaps of morphine and valium at the end.  ; )As far as life after death goes, I do believe our deceased loved ones are with us at the end. According to all the NDE testimony that I've read, the various types of religion (if any) makes absolutely no difference whatsoever when it comes to moving on after death. I also found it rather interesting that if the person wanted to see Jesus, Allah, Buddha, or some other Deity, then that's exactly who appeared to them. Well that, along with the typical report of seeing a tunnel with a bright light and especially overwhelming feelings of unconditional love as well. (Shrug)Btw- I actually know of two elderly people who experienced a NDE. Both of these people had requested 'Full Code' status on their Advanced directive. They both died during surgery and were and resuscitated. But upon their arrival back to the long term nursing care facility, I noticed that they both had changed their 'Advanced directive' from a 'Full Code' to a 'No Code' status. So I asked both of them for a confirmation regarding this change. (Especially since they were both afraid to die.) And yes, they both pretty much reported the same reasons as to why they no longer wanted 'Full Code' status. That when they died, they reported seeing their deceased loved ones in a landscape of indescribable beauty. That their loved ones had hugged them in a reunion of pure joy, and that they could feel the cocoon of "Gods" unconditional love embrace them. That 'IF' they had ONLY known what was waiting for them on the other side, that they never, EVER would have requested a Full-Code status! In fact they both went through a period of depression that they never fully snapped out of. They kept telling me how much they regretted their 'Full Code" decision and that every day they longed to return to what they both believed was Heaven. Lastly, I tend to believe in reincarnation myself. I also tend to believe that we are held accountable for our behavior towards not only each other but to this planet we call home...

For anyone wondering about what happens to your conciousness after your body stops working: not much really, it will just keep going the way it did before. Sure, there will be some memory loss but otherwise it's just fine; it's the same situation as when you were born, except on the other end of the loop.

You can think death as a kind of door. We all go trough it but it's not such a big deal in the end; it only lasts a second.

The real problem about death comes when we identify too much with our bodies or minds. Of course we aren't just that. We are parts of the bigger continuum; the universe, and that is of course a lot bigger than just the star systems and galaxies because it encompasses all the unseen dimensions and wavelengths that we have no idea about.

Hope this helps.

I always think this "What happens after death" topic will remain with an incomplete answer forever. You can only tell what happens to those things you can see but what about those that you can't, if there even are any that is, right? But how can you tell for sure? I always like to ask myself this question when I feel that I know too much about reality as it is, a pretty arrogant question, which is "Do you really think a pathetic mortal human like you can know it all? A wind of dust traveling the unknown vacuum of space with no purpose, no goal, and no reason whatsoever. How could such a waste of space claim to have full knowledge of everything?" Well what if someone smarter than me can? But what is being smart or intelligent after all? Someone that just knows a lot right? But how can you call yourself smart or intelligent when you only know so much, and will only know so much. Our intelligence and ability to understand is limited due to our perspective of reality as it is. We can claim full knowledge of those things we can see, but that simply isn't enough because the opposite as it is right now will remain unknown until someone or something can uncover those mysteries, if they're even to exists.

Anyways, that's just my 2 cents. What I'm trying to say is that there will always be room for speculation and whatever that is, it will never be right or wrong. So don't be too afraid or insecure to believe in something or the opposite, to doubt it.

CO2 from decay causes a rise in acidity of the tissues. That makes pH FALL, not rise. Your body doesn't become more basic (pH > 7), but more acidic (pH < 7). It goes from a buffered value of around 7.2 (slightly basic) down to around 5 (sodas can have a pH as low as 2).

Everyone says "It's not fair that we have to die" but the way I look at it is; there was a veryyyy small probability that you were born. All of your ancestors had to have survived at least up until they reproduced. Then you had to had to beat millions of other sperm to reach the egg. Then you had to survive in the womb. The list goes on and on. The chance of you being born is like winning the ultimate jackpot. You get around 80 years of life, while the sperm that you beat will never get any life at all. They will always be stuck in our perception of death. It is fair that we die, because in reality, everyone who was ever born won the jackpot when the odds were stacked against them trillions to one

You don't really die because theoretically you're not even alive.

The cell is not something alive, it is just a mechanical part that is moved by proteins and proteins are just a bunch of chains of amino acids/molecules etc so the protein and the cell are just moved by the laws of nature, and we are made out of cells, so basically we're just highly complex machine made out of smaller machines and moved by the laws of the nature.

As for our brains, well, the informations stored in our brains are just some electrical signals, so our brain is like a big archive machine that also somehow manages to control some of our actions, but overall we're just theoretically... ...not alive. And when we die, all those elements will make some different body or thing, just like those elements made you, who knows, maybe some atoms of the Einstein's body is now part of yours :)

And you're the same age as the Universe because the matter cannot be created or destroyed, it is just there, always

The word "death" doesn't really have a scientific meaning. Science can catalog changes in metabolic state. But saying that this set of states is "alive" or "human life" and anything else is not is a value assignment, not science. Whether you put the line at general brain death, irreversible loss of consciousness, brain stem death, cessation of heartbeat or what have you is a decision of an ethicist. One ought to only rely on an ethicist who is well informed on the science, but one can't rely on the science alone.
